#Text=Irish phrasebook
#Text=Irish ( Gaeilge ) is one of the three Goidelic languages , the others being Scottish Gaelic and Manx .
#Text=This Goidelic branch together with the Brythonic branch ( Welsh , Cornish and Breton ) form the Celtic language family .
#Text=These are spoken in parts of Ireland , the United Kingdom and France .
#Text=Irish is compulsory in schools in the Republic of Ireland , but spoken as a first language only by a minority of the Irish population .
#Text=It is also taught in Catholic schools in Northern Ireland , but is in general much rarer than in the Republic .
#Text=Practically all native Irish speakers are also able to speak English , so learning Irish is not necessary to communicate .
#Text=That said , many place names and personal names are in Irish , so at the very least , knowledge of Irish pronunciation is useful for getting around and meeting people .
#Text=Some common features of the Celtic languages which strike learners as odd are :
#Text=' mutations ' : sounds change , often at the beginning of words , as part of the grammar , e.g. cat ' cat ' , but mo chat ' my cat '
#Text=the verb is usually at the beginning of the sentence
#Text=prepositional pronouns that are conjugated , e.g. agam ' at me ' , agat ' at you ' , etc.
#Text=Pronunciation guide

#Text=There are three major dialects in Irish , named for the three provinces in the north ( Ulster , major cities Derry and Belfast ) , west ( Connacht , major city Galway ) and south ( Munster , major cities Cork , Limerick , Waterford ) of the island .
#Text=The eastern province , ( Leinster , major cities Dublin , Kilkenny ) , no longer has its own distinct dialect .
#Text=The Caighdeán Oifigiúl ( kaigh-DAWN iffig-OOL , official standard ) has been in place since the mid-20th century after spelling was ' regularised ' ( to an extent ) .
#Text=This is the official Irish that appears in phrasebooks and in Government publications .
#Text=It is largely the same as the Munster dialect , with a very few exceptions .
#Text=There are great differences in pronunciation between the dialects , with Munster differing the most from the other two .
#Text=For example ' tá go maith ' , ' yes indeed ' is pronounced ' TAY guh MAIGH ' in Ulster but ' TAW guh MAH ' in Connacht and Munster .
#Text=There are also differences in the phrases used in everyday speech .
#Text=In the phrasebook below , the Munster phrase has been used except where indicated .
#Text=The conjugation of verbs , too , differs from dialect to dialect .
#Text=Munster uses a contracted form in the past and present first person and in the third person of all three tenses .
#Text=For example ' tá mé ' ( ' TAW MAY ' , I am ) is ' táim ' ( ' TAW 'm ' ) in Munster , and ' bhí mé ' ( VEE MAY , I was ) is ' bhíos ' ( VEE-us ) in Munster .
#Text=Vowels
#Text=These are the pronunciations of the vowels when stressed ( stress with word-initial ) .
#Text=Unstressed short vowels ( not marked with an accent ) are generally pronounced like an ' uh ' sound .
#Text=a : like ' o ' in " cod "
#Text=á : like ' aw ' in " flaw "
#Text=e : like ' e ' in " peg "
#Text=é : like ' ay ' in " hay "
#Text=i : like ' i ' in " tin "
#Text=í : like ' ee ' in " heel "
#Text=o : like ' u ' in " bud "

column1: #Text=ó : like ' o ' in " home "
#Text=u : like ' u ' in " bud "
#Text=ú : like ' oo ' in " cool "

#Text=note : vowel combinations/diphthongs in Irish ( e. g. ' G aei lge , ' s ea cht ai n ) are slightly rounded and pronounced in the back of the mouth without using the lips at all . ( e. g. ' Gaeilge ' should not , strictly speaking , be pronounced with a w after the g. ) Thus , correct pronunciation can be obtained only from imitating spoken Irish , but the pronunciation guide given here is an adequate enough approximation in that by using it , you will be perfectly understood by any Irish speaker .
#Text=Consonants
#Text=Consonant combinations with h are sometimes written with a dot ( séimhiú , shay-VOO ) on the letter instead of the h and are sometimes silent .

#Text=All consonants have two versions called caol ( narrow , palatalized ) and leathan ( wide , velarized ) ( except for h , which is neither palatalized or velarized ) ; this is indicated in writing by adjacent vowels .
#Text=As a rule , if the nearest vowel is a , o , or u , the consonant is broad .
#Text=If the nearest vowel is e or i , it is slender .
#Text=b : like b ed
#Text=bh : like W sound when broad ; like a V sound when slender
#Text=c : like k id when broad ; like the ty in Hungarian when slender ( does not occur in English )
#Text=ch : as is Scottish ' loch ' when broad ; like h igh or German ich when slender
#Text=d : like d og but sometimes slightly softer , like the Icelandic ð or th in th em , often like the English ' j ' when followed by an ' e ' or ' i '
#Text=dh : voiced h sound when broad , y when slender ; sometimes vague gh sound ( Munster dialect especially ) , always silent after long vowels
#Text=f : like f un
#Text=fh : silent ( except in Ulster , where it 's said like an h )
#Text=g : like g o when broad ; like the gy in Hungarian when slender ( does not occur in English , with the closest approximation probably being the d in the French d ure )
#Text=gh : see dh
#Text=h : like h elp
#Text=l : like l ean
#Text=m : like m other
#Text=mh : same as bh but slightly softer
#Text=n : like n ice
#Text=ng : like si ng when broad and word initial ( follow with a broad g otherwise ) ; like o ni on when slender and word initial ( follow with a slender g otherwise )
#Text=p : like p ig
#Text=ph : like ph one or wh om
#Text=r : like r at when broad ; like zh sound in vi s ion when slender
#Text=s : like s oon when broad ; like sheen when slender
#Text=sh : like h ear
#Text=t : like th in ' the ' , or occasionally like t in ' tin ' , depending on its placement in the word ; sometimes pronounced as the English ' ch ' in China when slender
#Text=th : like h ear
#Text=Common diphthongs
#Text=Diphthongs are generally irregular and can be learned only by experience .

#Text=For example , ' ai ' in " Corcaigh " ( the city and county of Cork ) is pronounced like the ' i ' in " dig " but the ' ai ' in " faic " ( nothing ) is pronounced like the ' a ' in " hack " , and the ' ai ' in " haigh !
